title: Add Support for Integrated Terminal Context in Copilot Chat

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Feature Request
Currently, GitHub Copilot Chat in VS Code does not have access to the integrated terminal’s command history or process output unless the user manually copies and pastes it into the chat.

Problem:

Copilot Chat can see open files and diffs, but cannot “remember” or reference previous terminal commands or logs automatically.

This limits its ability to help with debugging, build issues, or process monitoring without extra manual steps.

Proposed Solution:

Provide an option to capture the integrated terminal’s last N lines of output and include them in Copilot Chat’s context automatically.

Allow toggling terminal context collection on/off for privacy.

Optionally allow persistent session awareness so Copilot can reference commands run earlier in the same workspace.

Benefits:

Faster debugging workflow (no copy/paste needed)

More helpful AI responses for build failures, runtime errors, and CLI-based development

Improves the agent’s usability for DevOps, backend, and CLI-heavy projects

Example:

User runs npm run build → Copilot automatically sees the error log and suggests fixes without extra input.

title: gpt-5 work
body:
Type: Performance Issue I tested gpt-5 in VS Code when it was released. It worked AMAZING! It didn't require a lot of supervision, my requests were handled thoughtfuly, strategically, it did minimum mistakes. The speed of my coding increased significantly. I ran out of the requests allowed within my subscription so I set a budget to be able to continue using this great more. Then on August 13 it all changed. gpt-5 became working worse than other models: it became slower, didn't follow my instructions with thought, many mistakes started occur. Before Aug 13 gpt-5 could change 200 lines of code and completely fulfill my request, and now I have to switch to another model because it became working much much worse. What happened? title: VSCode thinks #add is a color, even when it's a class method
body:
Type: Bug * Open/create a new, blank file * Change language mode to "typescript" * Write this: ``` class MyClass { #add() {} } ``` * Notice how the `#add` method is interpreted by VSCode as a color Even though MyClass.#add is a method, VSCode think it's a color and adds the color selection on the left side of the method name. I guess the same goes for any three-letter method name, where the letters are a-f. title: Deprecated extensions notification persists after dismissal in Extensions sidebar

labels.name: polish
labels.description: Cleanup and polish issue

labels.name: extensions
labels.description: Issues concerning extensions

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->

**Issue Type:** Bug

**Title:** Deprecated extensions notification persists after dismissal in Extensions sidebar

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No (the notification is about deprecated extensions, so it requires extensions to be installed)

- VS Code Version: 1.104.0-insider (Universal)
- OS Version: macOS 15.6 (Darwin arm64 24.6.0)

**Additional Version Information:**
- Commit: a61e381bfa71c241738e48f2fc8b01eade94c91d
- Date: 2025-08-14T20:20:09.764Z
- Electron: 37.2.3
- ElectronBuildId: 12035395
- Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
- Node.js: 22.17.0
- V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0

**Description:**
In the Extensions sidebar, when there are deprecated extensions installed, a notification appears saying "Deprecated extensions detected. Review them and migrate to alternatives." with an X button to dismiss it. However, clicking the X button to close this notification does not permanently dismiss it - the message reappears every time the Extensions sidebar is accessed or refreshed.

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Open VSCode Insiders with deprecated extensions installed
2. Navigate to the Extensions sidebar (Cmd+Shift+X on Mac)
3. Observe the yellow warning notification: "Deprecated extensions detected. Review them and migrate to alternatives. Show"
4. Click the X button on the right side of the notification to dismiss it
5. Close and reopen the Extensions sidebar, or restart VSCode
6. Return to the Extensions sidebar

**Expected Behavior:**
The deprecated extensions notification should be permanently dismissed after clicking the X button and should not reappear until the user installs new deprecated extensions or the dismissal state is reset.

**Actual Behavior:**
The notification reappears every time the Extensions sidebar is accessed, despite being dismissed multiple times with the X button.

**Screenshots:**
[Attach the screenshot you provided showing the deprecated extensions notification]

**Additional Context:**
- This issue persists across VSCode restarts
- The notification appears to have no persistent dismissal state
- Similar notifications in other parts of VSCode typically remember their dismissal state
- The "Show" link in the notification works correctly to display the deprecated extensions

title: Copilot Chat: grep_search fails with multiple folders
body: - Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.31.2025081401 - VS Code Version: 1.104.0-insider (Universal) - OS Version: Darwin arm64 24.6.0 - Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): agent - Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): GPT-5 - Logs: Steps to Reproduce: 1. Use GPT-5 (happens with Claude Sonnet 4 also) in Agent mode. 2. Ask it to give you information in your code files or tests. e.g., ```markdown Describe exactly how I can run the multi_replace_string_in_file tool to me in this codebase. I would like to test it out with an example problem that I have. Also, point me towards the tests so I can add a test. ``` 3. Observe how it uses grep_search **Expected:** It uses proper globbing to find the lines of code in files. **Actual:** It uses `(**/src/**|test/**)` to search in files which isn't a valid glob: ### Example tool call it made: ```markdown # Tool Call - call_4Fdc0CL2nRUsDm7UsY8v1HvN__vscode-1755212366059 ## Request ~~~ id : call_4Fdc0CL2nRUsDm7UsY8v1HvN__vscode-1755212366059 tool : grep_search args : { "query": "multi_replace_string_in_file|copilot_multiReplaceString", "isRegexp": true, "includePattern": "src/**|test/**" } ~~~ ## Response ~~~ No matches found ~~~ ``` ## Notes It looks like the problem is in the description of the tool and the includePattern field: ```markdown prefer using regex patterns with alternation (|) or character classes to search ``` Then later in `includePattern`: ```markdown use a proper glob pattern like \"src/folder/**\". Do not use | in includePattern. ``` It looks like the model cannot see the `|` by itself and might be looking for `(|)`. ## Suggestion Rather than correcting the `|` to `(|)`, give it a better example. Update `includePattern`'s description to be: ```json "description": "Match files using this valid glob pattern (not regex), applied to workspace-relative paths. Use ** for recursive search (e.g. \"src/folder/**\"). Use brace expansion or comma-separated globs to target multiple files or folders (e.g. \"src/{folder1,folder2,folder3}/**\", \"src/**/*{.ext1,ext2,ext3}\", \"src/folder1/**,src/folder2/**\")." ```

title: Can't define program field in launch.json in a generic way for remote tests

labels.name: *caused-by-extension
labels.description: Issue identified to be caused by an extension

body: Type: Feature Request From about in Vscode ``` Version: 1.103.0 Commit: e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f Date: 2025-08-06T21:40:10.271Z Electron: 37.2.3 ElectronBuildId: 12035395 Chromium: 138.0.7204.100 Node.js: 22.17.0 V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0 OS: Linux x64 6.8.0-71-generic snap ``` Contents of Build Host's /etc/os-release: ``` $ cat /etc/os-release PRETTY_NAME="Ubuntu 24.04.3 LTS" NAME="Ubuntu" VERSION_ID="24.04" VERSION="24.04.3 LTS (Noble Numbat)" VERSION_CODENAME=noble ID=ubuntu ID_LIKE=debian HOME_URL="https://www.ubuntu.com/" SUPPORT_URL="https://help.ubuntu.com/" BUG_REPORT_URL="https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/" PRIVACY_POLICY_URL="https://www.ubuntu.com/legal/terms-and-policies/privacy-policy" UBUNTU_CODENAME=noble LOGO=ubuntu-logo ``` I am cross-compiling to a Raspberry Pi 2 W target device. I am creating tests in a cross-compile environment and want to debug them. I don't want to have to create a separate launch.json configuration for each test. Since I have to run the tests remotely I had to define the COMMAND in add_test to be a shell that copied the test to the target and then executed it there. ``` add_test( NAME UnitsPressureTests WORKING_DIRECTORY ${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR} COMMAND ${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/cmake/run_remote_test.sh units_pressure_test --gtest_output=json:units_pressure_test_results.json --gtest_filter=UnitsPressureTest.*) ``` The run_remote_test.sh just simply copies the file to the target and runs it: ``` #!/bin/bash REMOTE_HOST="chrisk@qwtest.local" REMOTE_PATH="/usr/local/qw/tests" LOCAL_BINARY="$1" # TestExecutable shift # Remove the first argument # Transfer the binary scp "${LOCAL_BINARY}" "${REMOTE_HOST}:${REMOTE_PATH}/" # Execute remotely and capture result ssh "${REMOTE_HOST}" "cd ${REMOTE_PATH} && ./${LOCAL_BINARY} $@" exit $? ``` When I run this test it works perfectly fine. I create a launch.json configuration so I can debug it as below: ``` { "name": "Debug Tests", "cwd": "${cmake.testWorkingDirectory}", "request": "launch", "program": "${cmake.testProgram}", "args": ["${cmake.testArguments}"], "type": "cppdbg", "MIMode": "gdb", "miDebuggerPath": "/usr/bin/gdb-multiarch", "miDebuggerArgs": "", "miDebuggerServerAddress": "192.168.50.6:4711", "targetArchitecture": "arm64", "stopAtEntry": false, "preLaunchTask": "StartUnitTestGDBServer", "postDebugTask": "StopUnitTestGDBServer" } ``` I need a preLaunchTask because I have to copy the executable to the remote host and start the gdbserver over there. When I try to debug a test with this configuration I get an error: ``` GDB failed with message: "/home/chrisk/Projects/RaspberryPi/WS/cmake/run_remote_test.sh":not in executable format:file format not recognized. ``` It seems that ${cmake.testProgram} is defined as the first string after COMMAND in add_test. In my case it is the shell script run_remote_test.sh which copies the test to the remote and runs the test on the remote. If I didn't need to run the test on the remote then the first string after COMMAND would probably be the executable. Maybe add_test should have an EXECUTABLE option that defines a ${cmake.testExecutable} variable that can be used for the launch.json's program field: ``` add_test( NAME UnitsPressureTests EXECUTABLE ${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR}/units_pressure_test WORKING_DIRECTORY ${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR} COMMAND ${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/cmake/run_remote_test.sh units_pressure_test --gtest_output=json:units_pressure_test_results.json --gtest_filter=UnitsPressureTest.*) ``` As it is right now it appears I need a separate launch.json configuration for each test so I can define the program field with the path for each unique test. Just a thought. Thanks Chris VS Code version: Code 1.103.0 (e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f, 2025-08-06T21:40:10.271Z) OS version: Linux x64 6.8.0-71-generic snap Modes:

title: Copilot keeps reappearing even after disabling it / trying to remove it
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: I don't know

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->

- VS Code Version: 1.103.1
- OS Version: MacOS 15.6 (24G84)

Currently installed extensions:

* mohsen1.prettify-json-0.0.3
* mtxr.sqltools-0.28.4
* davidanson.vscode-markdownlint-0.60.0
* ms-azuretools.vscode-docker-2.0.0
* ms-vscode-remote.remote-containers-0.422.1
* ms-azuretools.vscode-containers-2.1.0
* ms-python.vscode-python-envs-1.2.0-darwin-arm64
* ms-python.vscode-pylance-2025.7.1
* ms-python.debugpy-2025.10.0-darwin-arm64
* vue.volar-3.0.5
* ms-python.python-2025.12.0-darwin-arm64
* docker.docker-0.15.0-darwin-arm64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VSCode
2. Occasionally the Copilot chat panel opens even when I've disabled it

I have disabled copilot because I don't like hallucinating goblins trying to help me with things, and the copilot panel will still occasionally show up, and I have to close it again.

If I could have a Visual Studio Code without copilot I would.

If I could have a Visual Studio Code that remembers my preferences with Copilot, that would also be good.

If you could somehow convince your PHBs that not everyone needs the drug-addled soulless language mannequins to help with their code, that would also be acceptable, provided I don't have to interact with it.

If there was a way to disable this "feature" with a command line flag, that would also be acceptable.

If there is already an issue which covers this, I apologize; I attempted to find an issue about copilot being forced down our collective throats like an alien facehugger implanting a xenomorph but apparently I'm alone in this.

Download Visual Studio Code, Download Marlin Firmare, Downloaded C/C++, Downloaded Auto Build Marlin, Downloaded GitHub Copilot and Chat, Downloaded PlatformIO IDE, Downloaded Pylance, Python Debugger, and WSL. The goal for me is to copy the firmware onto the mini chip, right. I do not see checkmark, src, pins.h on my screen. Any step by step suggestions to make this project complete. I am struggling right now. Your response will be appreciated. Thank you so kindly. title: VS Code Remote SSH to TACC connects, but file explorer freezes and terminal becomes unresponsive
body:
Type: Bug I'm encountering a problem when using Visual Studio Code to connect to the TACC (Texas Advanced Computing Center) supercomputer using the "Remote - SSH" extension. I can successfully connect to the remote host via "Connect to Host" in VS Code, but as soon as I try to open the file explorer or browse folders on the remote, nothing loads, and VS Code becomes unresponsive. The terminal in VS Code also freezes, and I can’t run any commands after that. A few details: 1. I’m using a compatible version of VS Code (latest stable). 2. I can SSH into TACC just fine using my terminal on my laptop. Any ideas on what might be causing this or how I can debug further? Thanks in advance! Version: 1.101.1 (Universal)
Commit: 18e3a1ec544e6907be1e944a94c496e302073435
Date: 2025-06-18T13:35:12.605Z (1 mo ago)
Electron: 35.5.1
ElectronBuildId: 11727614
Chromium: 134.0.6998.205
Node.js: 22.15.1
V8: 13.4.114.21-electron.0
OS: Darwin arm64 24.6.0

Steps to Reproduce:

terminal events are being fired twice for fish 4 (e.g. `vscode.window.onDidStartTerminalShellExecution` and `vscode.window.onDidEndTerminalShellExecution`). while vscode doesn't directly use these, this is breaking my downstream extension specifically for fish 4 users :(. i believe this is because fish 4 now automatically sends final term sequences, but we still inject shellintegration.fish which fires vscode sequences. this causes like every event to get emitted twice by both sequence handlers.

would be happy to work on a fix if pointed in the right direction. one hacky solution i've found is adding the following to the top of https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/8dae30a5c61163f5d3120e20adaae8b213226465/src/vs/platform/terminal/common/xterm/shellIntegrationAddon.ts#L385-L392 but i'm not sure if this is the right thing to do.
```ts
		if (this._status !== ShellIntegrationStatus.Off && this._status !== ShellIntegrationStatus.FinalTerm) {
			return false;
		}
```

title: Add telemetry event for chat mode switching
body:
This PR adds telemetry tracking for when users switch between different chat modes (Ask, Edit, Agent, and custom modes). This will provide valuable insights into how users interact with chat mode switching functionality.

## Changes

### New Telemetry Event: `chat.modeChange`

Added comprehensive telemetry capture in the `ToggleChatModeAction.run()` method that tracks:

- **`fromMode`**: The previous chat mode ID (string)
- **`toMode`**: The new chat mode ID (string) 
- **`requestCount`**: Number of requests in the current chat session (number)

### Implementation Details

The telemetry follows the established VS Code patterns:

```typescript
type ChatModeChangeClassification = {
    owner: 'aeschli';
    comment: 'Reporting when Chat mode is switched between different modes';
    fromMode?: { classification: 'SystemMetaData'; purpose: 'FeatureInsight'; comment: 'The previous chat mode' };
    toMode?: { classification: 'SystemMetaData'; purpose: 'FeatureInsight'; comment: 'The new chat mode' };
    requestCount?: { classification: 'SystemMetaData'; purpose: 'FeatureInsight'; comment: 'Number of requests in the current chat session'; 'isMeasurement': true };
};
```

The telemetry event is sent whenever `ToggleChatModeAction` detects an actual mode change, capturing the transition state while maintaining privacy by excluding sensitive data.

## Use Cases

This telemetry will help understand:
- How frequently users switch between different chat modes
- Which chat modes are most commonly used
- Usage patterns across different session lengths
- Mode switching behavior in relation to conversation context

The implementation maintains backward compatibility and follows the same patterns as existing chat telemetry events.

### Steps to Reproduce: 1. Ensure that `chat.promptFiles` is enabled in settings. 2. Create a prompt file at `.github/prompts/001-sample.prompt.md` with the following content: ```markdown --- mode: ask --- Output "Hello" in 7 languages ``` 3. In the Copilot Chat input, type `/001-sample`. 4. Send the message. ### Expected Behavior: - When typing `/001-sample`, the text should be highlighted, indicating that Copilot has recognized the prompt file. - After sending, Copilot should respond with "Follow instructions in 001-sample.prompt.md." and execute the instructions from the prompt file. See behavior in 1.102.3: ### Actual Behavior: - When typing `/001-sample`, the text is not highlighted. (This occurs in v1.103.0 and later) - After sending, Copilot provides a generic response unrelated to the content of the prompt file. See behavior in 1.103.0 and later: ### Additional Information: - This issue started occurring after updating from VS Code version 1.102.3 to 1.103.0. - The issue persists in version 1.103.1. - Prompt files with names that do not contain numbers (e.g., `sample.prompt.md`) are recognized correctly. - It seems this is a regression caused by a change in Pull Request #255402, specifically in `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/common/chatRequestParser.ts`. The regular expression for slash commands was changed from `const slashReg = /^\/([\w_\-\.:]+)(?=(\s|$|\b))/i;` to `const slashReg = /^\/([\p{L}_\-\.:]+)(?=(\s|$|\b))/iu;`. The new regex uses `\p{L}` which matches Unicode letters but not digits, causing prompt file names with numbers to be ignored.

title: Add Open Active Diff Side option to Command Palette using DIFF_OPEN_SIDE command
body: Addresses issue #260762. This adds the `workbench.action.compareEditor.openSide` or `DIFF_OPEN_SIDE` constant in to the `MenuRegistry`, which registers it into the Command Palette. Below is a screenshot showing it in the command palette. ## How to Test 1. Open Visual Studio Code. 2. Open a folder with two files. 3. Select one file for compare in the Explorer pane by right-clicking it and click `Select for Compare` in the context menu. 4. Select another file by right-clicking it and clicking on `Compare with Selected` in the context menu. 5. The diff viewer should now open. Click on one of the file editors. This can be either side. 6. Open the Command Palette by hitting CTRL + SHIFT + P (Command/Cmd for Mac, instead of CTRL). 7. Look for "Open File on Selected Side". Click it while the desired file editor on either side is selected. 8. The desired file should be opened on its own.

title: Feature Request: Customizable continuous actions per chat mode file

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: chat-prompts
labels.description: Prompt and Instruction files related issues

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

When in agent mode, we currently have to set how many messages in vscode's settings before it asks if we want to continue, can this be added to the chat mode file as well? Sometimes you may only want 5 actions done, other times you may want 10 or if you are going let code Jesus take the wheel set like 500. It would be nice to have a chatmode file dictate how many continuous actions before being asked to continue or not in conjunction to settings.

A primary usage case would be like a debug chat mode agent, you'd want maybe 2 or 3 actions done to verify and test so on, as debugging should only be done in increments not like 200 actions. A feature case would be maybe like 10 actions done before you review and make corrections. A build up from nothing case might want 100 actions done before doing anything and mold the project afterwards.

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

**Feature Request: Voice Commands for Code Generation and Navigation**

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
I'd like built-in voice recognition that understands natural language programming commands. For example, saying "create a function that validates email addresses" would generate appropriate code, or "go to UserService class" would navigate to that file.

**Problem Statement:**
Constant typing causes RSI issues and limits accessibility for developers with mobility challenges. Existing voice coding solutions require complex setup and don't integrate well with the development workflow.

**Proposed Solution:**
- Natural language code generation via voice commands
- Voice-controlled navigation ("go to line 50", "find function getUserData")
- Code editing commands ("add error handling", "rename this variable to userCount")
- Context-aware suggestions based on current file and project

**Benefits:**
- Reduced RSI from excessive typing
- Better accessibility for developers with disabilities
- Faster prototyping and brainstorming
- Hands-free coding during architectural discussions

**Implementation Ideas:**
- Use Web Speech API (available in Electron)
- Integrate with existing language servers for context
- Local processing for privacy concerns
- Extensible command system for custom voice commands
- Machine learning for intent recognition

title: Feature Request: Interactive Timeline Scrubber for File History

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: git
labels.description: GIT issues

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

**Feature Request: Interactive Timeline Scrubber for File History**

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
I'd like an interactive timeline component at the bottom of the editor that lets me scrub through a file's git history in real-time. As I drag the timeline slider, the editor content would update to show different versions of the file with smooth transitions.

**Problem Statement:**
Understanding how code evolved over time requires manually checking out commits or using git log, which breaks development flow. Current timeline view in VS Code shows history but isn't interactive for exploring changes.

**Proposed Solution:**
- Horizontal timeline scrubber UI component (similar to video players)
- Real-time file content updates while dragging
- Visual indicators for major vs minor changes
- Ability to pin specific versions for comparison
- Smooth animations showing code additions/deletions

**Benefits:**
- Faster debugging by seeing when bugs were introduced
- Better understanding of code evolution
- Enhanced code archaeology for unfamiliar codebases
- More intuitive than traditional git interfaces

**Implementation Ideas:**
- Extend existing Timeline API functionality
- Use VS Code's diff engine for change visualization
- Implement caching for smooth scrubbing performance
- Integrate with current source control providers

title: Feature Request: Visual Code Health Indicator in File Explorer
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

**Feature Request: Visual Code Health Indicator in File Explorer**

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
I'd like VS Code to show visual indicators (colored dots or backgrounds) in the file explorer that represent code health based on factors like complexity, bug frequency, and maintenance burden. Files would be color-coded - red for high-risk areas, yellow for medium attention needed, green for stable code.

**Problem Statement:**
Working on large codebases, it's difficult to identify which files need attention without diving deep into each one. I waste time on code that looks fine but has hidden complexity or frequent bugs.

**Proposed Solution:**
- Add colored visual indicators to files in the explorer tree
- Use metrics like cyclomatic complexity, git change frequency, and bug patterns
- Allow customization of which factors determine health scores
- Integrate with existing code analysis tools and git history

**Benefits:**
- Quick visual identification of problematic code areas
- Better prioritization of refactoring efforts
- Helps new team members avoid high-risk areas
- Data-driven development decisions

**Implementation Ideas:**
- Leverage existing VS Code Decoration API
- Integrate with CodeMetrics extension data
- Analyze git history for change patterns
- Provide configuration options for health criteria

title: run_in_terminal tool fails to capture stdout from certain command-line tools despite successful redirection
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

## Environment Details

- **VS Code:** 1.103.0 (x64)
- **OS:** Windows 11 Build 26100
- **Shell:** PowerShell 7.5.2 Core
- **.NET:** 9.0.302
- **Copilot Chat Extension:** 0.30.1
- **GitHub Copilot Extension:** 1.350.0
- **Affected Tool:** BinlogTool 1.0.27
- **Feature:** run_in_terminal tool
- **AI Model:** Claude Sonnet 4

## Description

The `run_in_terminal` tool used by GitHub Copilot Chat fails to capture stdout output from certain command-line tools, even though the same commands:
1. Display output correctly in the terminal window
2. Can be successfully redirected to files (`> file.txt`)
3. Write to stdout (as proven by successful redirection)

This creates a disconnect where users can see output in their terminal, but the AI assistant cannot access the same information, forcing workarounds.

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Install BinlogTool: `dotnet tool install -g BinlogTool`
2. Have an MSBuild binary log file available (e.g., `msbuild.binlog`)
3. Use the `run_in_terminal` tool to execute: `binlogtool search msbuild.binlog "CS0656"`
4. Observe that the tool captures no output
5. Run the same command with redirection: `binlogtool search msbuild.binlog "CS0656" > output.txt`
6. Observe that the file contains the expected output (proving it writes to stdout)

## Expected Behavior

The `run_in_terminal` tool should capture the same output that is visible in the terminal and can be redirected to files.

## Actual Behavior

The tool captures no output, returning empty results despite the command producing visible output in the terminal.

## Impact

- AI assistants cannot analyze command output that users can clearly see
- Forces manual workarounds using file redirection and file reading
- Breaks the seamless integration between terminal commands and AI assistance
- Affects productivity when working with .NET tools and potentially other command-line utilities

## Additional Information

- This issue specifically affects certain .NET global tools like BinlogTool
- Other standard commands (echo, Get-Date, etc.) work correctly
- The problem appears to be with output capture mechanism, not with the commands themselves
- Workaround: Use file redirection (`command > temp.txt`) then read the file

## Test Case

```powershell
# This works and shows output in terminal but tool captures nothing:
binlogtool search msbuild.binlog "error"

# This works and creates file with content (proving stdout works):
binlogtool search msbuild.binlog "error" > errors.txt

# This allows AI to see the output:
Get-Content errors.txt
```
